main: Computer vision techniques effectively automate scoring of figural creativity tests.
details: A three-study investigation applied computer vision approaches to score drawn tests of creative thinking and ideation. The study achieved strong correlations with human scores, demonstrating the viability of automated creativity assessment across multiple test formats.

main: An analysis of how research leverages data types and visualizations in communication.
details: A large content analysis of JASIS&T journals, complemented by computer vision, sheds light on visual data in scholarly communication.

main: Scoring creativity with Large-Language models greatly improves on state of the art models.
details: Studying creativity is challenged by the difficulty of measuring and scoring tests of originality. We improved on automated scoring of one common test, the Alternate Uses Task, to a large degree.

main: Synthetic data can address class imbalance in digital library classifiers.
details: We seek to identify whole-part relationships between books, such as when one story is published in another anthology. This type of relationship is hard to infer from cataloguing metadata, but we find that constructing artificial books can teach a deep neural network classifier what the relationship looks like.

main: Research access over sensitive or restricted texts can be encouraged through non-expressive distribution strategies.
details: Text analysis in the digital humanities is challenged by legal hurdles, which make it difficult to access and especially to redistribute datasets of modern texts. We explore principles of non-expressive and non-consumptive access as one solution to enabling research access to sensitive texts.
